citations.narrative:
There is no record of the sale or disposition of 8 puppies that were present at the facility during the last inspection on April
29, 2025. There were 12 puppies at the facility during that inspection, and there are disposition records for the sale of 4
puppies on June 16, 2025, but the facility representative can not find records of the disposition of the other 8 puppies that
are not longer at the facility. Accurate records of the disposition of dogs are important because they provide a record of
movement of dogs between breeders, buyers, and facilities and are crucial in tracking disease outbreaks and monitoring
veterinary care and disease prevention in the kennel. Each dealer shall use Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats
(APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain information about all dogs that are sold or otherwise disposed of.

The facility did not keep adequate records for the medical care of 3 dogs. A facility calendar notes that "Snickers", a 3
year old female French Bulldog, had a prolapse on July15-16, but there are no other medical records regarding the event.
The facility representative did take the dog to the veterinarian and said Snickers was sent home with medications, but
there are no medical records of Snickers' treatment, what medications were prescribed, or when those medications were
given.
The calendar also notes that "Muffin", a 2 year old female French Bulldog, had a C-section June 18, 2025. The facility
representative confirms that Muffin was sent home with medications, but there are no records of Muffin's treatment, what
medications were prescribed, or when those medications were given.
A notebook mentions that "Princess", a 3 year old female French Bulldog, was taken to the veterinarian on June 17, 2025,
for a lump on her neck and was "prescribed antibiotic", but there is no other medical record of the treatment, what
medications were prescribed, or when those medications were given.
The completion of medical treatments and prescribed medications is very important for the health of dogs recovering
illness or surgery. Adequate medical records help guide those administering the treatments and are used by USDA
inspectors to confirm that treatments and medications prescribed for dogs are given properly and completely. Dealers
must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These records must
include the date and a description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and
treatment procedures performed.
To be corrected by: August 8, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(2)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There is no record of the sale or disposition of 8 puppies that were present at the facility during the last inspection on April 
29, 2025. There were 12 puppies at the facility during that inspection, and there are disposition records for the sale of 4 
puppies on June 16, 2025, but the facility representative can not find records of the disposition of the other 8 puppies that 
are not longer at the facility. Accurate records of the disposition of dogs are important because they provide a record of 
movement of dogs between breeders, buyers, and facilities and are crucial in tracking disease outbreaks and monitoring 
veterinary care and disease prevention in the kennel. Each dealer shall use Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats 
(APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain information about all dogs that are sold or otherwise disposed of. 
3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility did not keep adequate records for the medical care of 3 dogs. A facility calendar notes that "Snickers", a 3 
year old female French Bulldog, had a prolapse on July15-16, but there are no other medical records regarding the event. 
The facility representative did take the dog to the veterinarian and said Snickers was sent home with medications, but 
there are no medical records of Snickers' treatment, what medications were prescribed, or when those medications were 
given. 
The calendar also notes that "Muffin", a 2 year old female French Bulldog, had a C-section June 18, 2025. The facility 
representative confirms that Muffin was sent home with medications, but there are no records of Muffin's treatment, what 
medications were prescribed, or when those medications were given. 
A notebook mentions that "Princess", a 3 year old female French Bulldog, was taken to the veterinarian on June 17, 2025, 
for a lump on her neck and was "prescribed antibiotic", but there is no other medical record of the treatment, what 
medications were prescribed, or when those medications were given. 
The completion of medical treatments and prescribed medications is very important for the health of dogs recovering 
illness or surgery. Adequate medical records help guide those administering the treatments and are used by USDA 
inspectors to confirm that treatments and medications prescribed for dogs are given properly and completely. Dealers 
must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. These records must 
include the date and a description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and 
treatment procedures performed. 
To be corrected by: August 8, 2024

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
